channel.title: Login Packet Structure
channel.description:
[b]format:[/b] [code] packet_name { (bits){name} // description } [/code] [hr] [b]packets:[/b] [code] login_packet { 8 id; // 18 or 16 depending if you're reconnecting 8 size; // 57 + login_data.size 32 version; 8 lowmem; // 1 or 0 depending if it's the low memory version or not. 32 checksum1; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum2; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum3; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum4; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum5; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum6; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum7; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum8; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum9; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum10; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum11; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum12; // checksum of cache file 32 checksum13; // checksum of cache file login_data data; // rsa encrypted chunk }
login_data { 8 id; // always 10 32 keyA; // client generated 32 keyB; // client generated 32 keyC; // server generated 32 keyD; // server generated 32 uid; 64 user; // user name that is encoded into a long string pass; // password }
string { array8 bytes[]; // array byte values of the string 8 end; // the end of the string in the packet } [/code]
bit = 1 binary unit 8-bit = 1 byte; 16-bit = 2 byte = 1 short; 32-bit = 4 byte = 2 short = 1 int; 64-bit = 8 byte = 4 short = 2 int = 1 long; array# = array of bits # large;
Note that the format is "(bits) name // description". [hr] [b]description:[/b] [b]login_packet[/b] is the main packet for logging in, it uses the [b]login_data[/b] structure after it once it has been RSA encrypted. and [b]login_data[/b] uses the structure for streaming a string [b]string[/b]. If you look over the login routine, you can easily see how a world switcher that doesn't LOAD fresh on the new world is detected. The server keys can track you from one server to another, and if Jagex is smart, they should be like a phone number, a range of 4000 keys are assigned to each server. The id's tell the server how to interpret incoming packets. Key's A-D are used as the base key-pairs for the frame and bit encryption used in the game from then on out on "Frame" bytes for those who are acquainted with private servers, and "Opcode", which is the true name for "Frame" bytes... [i]Opcode[/i] being a conjunction of Operation + Code, literally meaning: The code which tells a system how to operate. They keys track you through instances, the uid's track you through computers. On [b]login_packet[/b] the [b][i]length[/i][/b] bits are used to extract the RSA encrypted [b]login_packet[/b]. The version is used to verify client versions, the byte for lowmem is a boolean telling it whether or not you are a low memory or a high memory client. Lastly, the checksums assure that you haven't edited the cache such as to make all things invisible except what you want a color clicker to see.
[size=16pt]Questions, comments, corrections?[/size]
[hr] [b]Q&A[/b] [quote="frank_, post:18, topic:24772"]the user name (called from a method as a long) and the password (in bytes) is called directly before the implementation of the RSA on the login packet[/quote] Uh, no. In the login method, the user name is converted from bytes to a long using "public long encode();" which they use to look up people in there database as 8 bytes for all user names is greater than varying length and varying byte values. Plus a comparison of numbers is faster than a comparison of bytes by far. As far as the password goes, you were 8 bits off. Oh, by the way, the "long user name" can be decrypted using "public static String-Wrapper decode(long l);"
[quote="Martin, post:17, topic:24772"]I'm really stuck on this one. I just want to make an auto-login. No password loggers or anything.
Help anyone?
I have this but what do I do with it? [code] is[0] = (int) (Math.random() * 9.9999999E7); is[1] = (int) (9.9999999E7 * Math.random()); [/code][/quote]
That is the client generated keys of packet [b]login_data[/b]. [hr] [b]Other Information[/b]
The key values are not used on a Socket, but on each stream independently. The keys that are generated normally are used as the Cypher for the outgoing stream. The keys then get 50 added onto each of them, and then it is used for the incoming stream's cypher.

item.title: Login Packet Structure
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:1, topic:30836”]format:

packet_name {
(bits){name} // description
}

[hr]
packets:

login_packet {
         8 id; // 18 or 16 depending if you're reconnecting
         8 size; // 57 + login_data.size
        32 version;
         8 lowmem; // 1 or 0 depending if it's the low memory version or not.
        32 checksum1; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum2; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum3; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum4; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum5; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum6; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum7; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum8; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum9; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum10; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum11; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum12; // checksum of cache file
        32 checksum13; // checksum of cache file
login_data data; // rsa encrypted chunk
}

login_data {
     8 id; // always 10
    32 keyA; // client generated
    32 keyB; // client generated
    32 keyC; // server generated
    32 keyD; // server generated
    32 uid;
    64 user; // user name that is encoded into a long
string pass; // password
}

string { 
array8 bytes[]; // array byte values of the string
     8 end; // the end of the string in the packet
}

bit = 1 binary unit
8-bit = 1 byte;
16-bit = 2 byte = 1 short;
32-bit = 4 byte = 2 short = 1 int;
64-bit = 8 byte = 4 short = 2 int = 1 long;
array# = array of bits # large;

Note that the format is “(bits) name // description”.
[hr]
description:
login_packet is the main packet for logging in, it uses the login_data structure after it once it has been RSA encrypted. and login_data uses the structure for streaming a string string. If you look over the login routine, you can easily see how a world switcher that doesn’t LOAD fresh on the new world is detected. The server keys can track you from one server to another, and if Jagex is smart, they should be like a phone number, a range of 4000 keys are assigned to each server. The id’s tell the server how to interpret incoming packets. Key’s A-D are used as the base key-pairs for the frame and bit encryption used in the game from then on out on “Frame” bytes for those who are acquainted with private servers, and “Opcode”, which is the true name for “Frame” bytes… Opcode being a conjunction of Operation + Code, literally meaning: The code which tells a system how to operate. They keys track you through instances, the uid’s track you through computers. On login_packet the length bits are used to extract the RSA encrypted login_packet. The version is used to verify client versions, the byte for lowmem is a boolean telling it whether or not you are a low memory or a high memory client. Lastly, the checksums assure that you haven’t edited the cache such as to make all things invisible except what you want a color clicker to see.

[size=16pt]Questions, comments, corrections?[/size]

[hr]
Q&A

the user name (called from a method as a long) and the password (in bytes) is called directly before the implementation of the RSA on the login packet

Uh, no. In the login method, the user name is converted from bytes to a long using “public long encode();” which they use to look up people in there database as 8 bytes for all user names is greater than varying length and varying byte values. Plus a comparison of numbers is faster than a comparison of bytes by far. As far as the password goes, you were 8 bits off. Oh, by the way, the “long user name” can be decrypted using “public static String-Wrapper decode(long l);”

I’m really stuck on this one. I just want to make an auto-login. No password loggers or anything.

Help anyone?

I have this but what do I do with it?

		is[0] = (int) (Math.random() * 9.9999999E7);
		is[1] = (int) (9.9999999E7 * Math.random());

That is the client generated keys of packet login_data.
[hr]
Other Information

The key values are not used on a Socket, but on each stream independently. The keys that are generated normally are used as the Cypher for the outgoing stream. The keys then get 50 added onto each of them, and then it is used for the incoming stream’s cypher.[/quote]Thankyou again for entirely redundant and generally known information!

Ahh, anyone who can use this information already knows it (would probably be better off referencing the code themselves), and everyone else has no use for it, wonderful.

Feel free to return if you come up with some content of consequence though ^_^.

Read full topic

item.title: Login Packet Structure
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

Uh, no. In the login method, the user name is converted from bytes to a long using “public long encode();” which they use to look up people in there database as 8 bytes for all user names is greater than varying length and varying byte values. Plus a comparison of numbers is faster than a comparison of bytes by far.

They use the halving algorithm on a sorted list. They could hash the username, but I guess collision-free hashes for 12 characters (although the range is limited) produce a digest greater of 64 bits, for which there is a machine language comparison instruction. And looking at the fact that the “tightened” 64 bit username is reversible, we can safely say it’s an effective solution.

Read full topic
